Reference Texts for CS 175

CS 175, Winter 2018

Below are links to some online textbooks that should be very useful as background reading for your projects. You do not need to read all of these, but should find them for very useful as a starting point for finding relevant material on a particular text analysis topic.

  • The NLTK book (online). (NLTK = Natural Language Toolkit). Everything you need to know about NLTK. See also the NLTK online documentation.

  • Introduction to Information Retrieval by Manning, Schutze, and Raghavan, Cambridge University Press, 2008. PDF and HTML versions online. A very useful introduction to basic concepts in text representation, term vocabularies, document classification and clustering, and more. Chapters 13-15 are likely to be relevant for many projects.

  • Speech and Language Processing (3rd ed draft) by Jurafsky and Martin. (This is an online draft of a not-yet-finished book). Has more AI/NLP content than the Manning et al text. Relevant chapters for projects may include chapters on Naive Bayes, Logistic Regression, Neural Nets, Vector Semantics, Lexicons, Information Extraction, Question Answering, and Dialog Systems and Chatbots.

  • Hands-on Machine Learning with Scikit-Learn and TensorFlow by Aurelie Geron, O'Reilly Media, 2017. (This link is to the online version of the text, accessible via the UCI library subscription to Safari Books. This is a very useful hands-on overview of machine learning algorithms with links to Python (scikit-learn and TensorFlow). Well worth taking a look at this book as background reading before and during your project. Jupyter notebooks for this book are also available online.
